IP2026035_syn_1:
Indication: Patient coughed up valve. Symptoms returned.
Sedation: Moderate (Midazolam/Fentanyl).
Findings: Apicoposterior segment open (valve missing). Anterior valve loose.
Action: Removed loose anterior valve -> Replaced with new valve. Placed new valve in empty Apicoposterior segment.
Result: LUL fully occluded (3 valves total).
Plan: D/C home. Clinic f/u 4-6 wks.
IP2026035_syn_2:
HISTORY: [REDACTED] of an endobronchial prosthesis followed by worsening dyspnea 3 months post-LUL BLVR.
PROCEDURE: Bronchoscopic inspection confirmed the absence of the valve in the apicoposterior segment. Additionally, the anterior segmental valve was noted to be migrating proximally with peri-valvular leak. The anterior valve was retrieved and replaced with a correctly sized unit. A de novo valve was deployed into the patent apicoposterior segment.
CONCLUSION: Restoration of complete lobar occlusion.

IP2026035:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with replacement of expectorated endobronchial valve and optimization of valve set, left upper lobe.
Patient: [REDACTED], 61-year-old female with severe heterogeneous emphysema status post LUL BLVR 3 months prior.
Sedation: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl; native airway with bite block.
Indication: Suspected valve loss after the patient reported coughing up an endobronchial valve at home, with subsequent increase in dyspnea and decline in exercise tolerance.
Background: The patient underwent LUL BLVR with four Zephyr valves 3 months earlier with good initial response. Over the past 2 weeks, she noted increased cough and exertional dyspnea and brought an expectorated valve to clinic. Spirometry showed loss of some of the initial FEV1 gain; CT demonstrated partial re-aeration of an LUL segment.
Procedure details: Under moderate sedation, a flexible bronchoscope was advanced through the mouth with bite block. The left bronchial tree was inspected. In the LUL, two valves were seen in stable position; one segmental bronchus (apicoposterior) was open without a valve, and one valve in the anterior segment appeared slightly proximal with visible ventilation around the frame. The proximal anterior valve was removed with retrieval forceps, collapsed, and withdrawn. A new Zephyr valve was deployed more distally in the anterior segment to achieve complete occlusion. A second new valve was then deployed in the apicoposterior segment to replace the expectorated valve. Final inspection showed three LUL segmental bronchi fully occluded with valves in stable positions.
Complications: None. No significant bleeding or hypoxemia.
Disposition: Observed for 2 hours post-procedure in bronchoscopy recovery and discharged home on baseline oxygen.
Plan: Clinic follow-up in 4â€“6 weeks with spirometry and symptom assessment; repeat CT at 3 months if clinically indicated.
